channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: I resigned from the CDC. Here are three questions for RFK Jr.
item.description: I resigned from the CDC. Here are three questions for RFK Jr.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Wedding opens new front in cold war with late wife’s sister
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Wedding opens new front in cold war with late wife’s sister

item.title: Florida moves to end vaccine mandates to attend school, the first state to do so
item.description: Florida Surgeon General Joseph A. Ladapo’s stances on vaccines and other measures have drawn criticism from public health experts and advocates, who have warned that the overhaul of vaccine policies could cause a resurgence of preventable diseases.

item.title: A high-profile split in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Wednesday points.

item.title: Deportation ruling. Space Command. Epstein files. China parade. ChatGPT controls. Wildfires. SNL cast. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Federal appellate panel rejects Trump’s deportations under Alien Enemies Act
item.description: The appellate panel ruled Tuesday that President Donald Trump unlawfully invoked the centuries-old wartime law to deport Venezuelan migrants, finding no invasion or “predatory incursion” had occurred to justify using the statute to fast-track migrant removals. The decision is widely expected to be appealed to the Supreme Court.

item.title: At an ICE career expo, a Marine veteran and a former MMA fighter are among thousands vying to carry out Trump’s deportation agenda
item.description: The administration is aiming to hire 10,000 new immigration officers next year, drumming up interest through militaristic branding and a signing bonus of up to $50,000 for top recruits. Applicants said they were not deterred by waning public support for the president's hardline approach.

item.title: First batch of Epstein files released by Congress
item.description: The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee released 33,295 pages of documents related to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. The committee said it was the first in a series of expected releases as a bipartisan group of lawmakers seeks more transparency from the Trump administration on the subject.

item.title: U.S. conducts ‘lethal strike’ on alleged drug vessel in Caribbean, a dramatic escalation as Trump intensifies focus on cartels
item.description: Administration officials said the operation targeted a boat that departed Venezuela and was operated by a “designated narco-terrorist organization.” It appeared to mark the first known time the Trump administration used deadly force to target illicit drug shipments originating in Latin America.

item.title: Federal judge bars Google from exclusive deals for its search engine but says it can keep Chrome in high-profile monopoly case
item.description: Judge Amit P. Mehta rejected prosecutors’ call to break up the Silicon Valley giant as he laid out remedies for his finding last year that it has an illegal monopoly in search.

item.title: D.C. Mayor Bowser welcomes federal law enforcement presence indefinitely, a sign of compliance with Trump
item.description: President Donald Trump’s federalization of the D.C. police force lasts 30 days and is set to expire next week. Mayor Muriel E. Bowser’s plans may quell a showdown over what happens after that deadline passes.

item.title: Trump intends to move U.S. Space Command headquarters from Colorado to Alabama, reversing Biden-era plan
item.description: The announcement, expected from President Donald Trump later Tuesday, marks the latest twist in a years-long partisan battle over the agency’s home.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Grandma’s offhand swipe at adoption gives couple pause
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Grandma’s offhand swipe at adoption gives couple pause

item.title: Trump’s deployment of National Guard troops to Los Angeles violated the law, judge rules in case brought by Gov. Gavin Newsom
item.description: The judge concluded that National Guard troops carried out domestic law enforcement actions, violating federal law. The judge did not order the remaining troops withdrawn but blocked them from certain actions.

item.title: A shakeup comes to this show in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Tuesday points.

item.title: Shutdown watch. Labor Day protests. Israel-Gaza. Gun safety. Green cement. Microplastics. Hat snatcher. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: We ranked 5,700 holidays. Which one's most popular on your birthday?
item.description: The Department of Data found the most (and least) official holidays for every day on the calendar.

item.title: This tracking protects a $600 billion economy. Cutting it is foolish.
item.description: This tracking protects a $600 billion economy. Cutting it is foolish.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: After a move and a baby, neither husband nor marriage is working
item.description: Carolyn Hax: After a move and a baby, neither husband nor marriage is working

item.title: A Labor Day quiz in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your holiday points.

item.title: Afghan quake. Blocked deportation. Trump’s power. Gaza plan. Medicaid cuts. Age verification. Geese trouble. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: More than 600 dead in earthquake in Afghanistan, officials say
item.description: The Taliban-run Interior Ministry said more than 1,500 others were injured after the 6.0-magnitude earthquake struck eastern Afghanistan. Damage and casualties were reported across the region, and the quake was felt in Kabul and neighboring Pakistan.

item.title: Postwar plan for Gaza circulating within the Trump administration envisions 'voluntary' relocation of entire population
item.description: It's not clear that the 38-page prospectus — which calls for turning Gaza into a trusteeship administered by the United States for at least 10 years while it is transformed into a tourism resort and manufacturing hub — is what President Donald Trump, who has vowed to "take over" the enclave, has in mind. But major elements of it, according to two people familiar with the planning, were designed to make real the president’s vision of a “Riviera of the Middle East.”

item.title: Judge orders administration to temporarily halt deportation of hundreds of Guatemalan children
item.description: A federal judge rushed an emergency hearing after learning that the Trump administration was moving to deport children to Guatemala despite an order she had issued early Sunday. The Justice Department said the government would ground planes carrying the children to their country of origin.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: ‘Gray rocking’ is a way to deal with difficult people. Here’s how it works.
item.description: Offering calm, disengaged responses — often referred to as the “gray rock method” — has become something of a phenomenon. Experts say the technique might quell conflict in some situations, but it’s not a long-term strategy.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: Ask Sahaj: ‘Heartbroken’ mom doesn’t believe her adult kid is trans
item.description: Ask Sahaj: ‘Heartbroken’ mom doesn’t believe her adult kid is trans

item.title: See how Africa wants to redraw the world map
item.description: The Mercator projection, a centuries-old map style from the age of sail, still prevails in the internet age. Here’s what the African Union wants to use instead.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: Judge temporarily blocks Trump administration from rapidly deporting most unauthorized immigrants without due process
item.description: The ruling comes after immigrant rights groups challenged the president’s broad expansion of expedited removal for migrants in the United States illegally and marks a setback for his mass deportation agenda.

item.title: Missouri’s Republican governor calls a special session to redraw the state’s congressional districts
item.description: Gov. Mike Kehoe announced a special session next week with the aim of gaining one more GOP seat in the U.S. House of Representatives. President Donald Trump has increased pressure on states to redraw congressional districts in hopes of beefing up his party’s chances of holding onto the House in the 2026 midterms.

item.title: Trump officials fire more than half a dozen EPA employees for signing letter criticizing the agency's leadership and direction
item.description: The move to terminate at least seven staffers marks an escalation in the administration’s effort to clamp down on dissent within the federal bureaucracy. EPA leaders had placed a total of 144 employees on leave for signing the letter nearly two months ago. Agency officials confirmed the firings, but did not say how many people had been let go.

item.title: Federal appeals court strikes down Trump's tariffs, a key part of his economic policy
item.description: The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit ruled that a 1977 law, called the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, or IEEPA, could not be used to impose most of Trump’s tariffs. The law is used in the case of threats against the country.

item.title: The 10 best college football towns in the country, according to our sports and travel writers
item.description: Fall colors. Buzzing student bodies. Alumni reliving glory days. If you visit any one of these towns before kickoff, you’ll feel the magic, and maybe learn a new cheer or two.

item.title: Republican Sen. Joni Ernst will not seek reelection in Iowa, people familiar with her decision say
item.description: The decision creates an opportunity for Democrats next year in their long-odds push to regain control of the Senate. Ernst was first elected to the Senate in 2014 and comfortably won reelection in 2020. Iowa has been a staunchly Republican state in recent elections, though the GOP has faced some political headwinds there this year.

item.title: Two Northern Virginia school districts sue Education Department as agency seeks to freeze funding over gender policies
item.description: The lawsuits filed by Arlington and Fairfax County public school districts come after the Education Department said it would require five Northern Virginia districts to seek reimbursement for certain federal grants, as well as begin the process of pulling other funding, in response to local leaders rejecting a call to change policies that allow students to use facilities like bathrooms and locker rooms that match their gender identity.

item.title: Happening now: Do you need a prescription for the new coronavirus vaccines? We’re answering your questions.
item.description: The Food and Drug Administration narrowed approval of new coronavirus vaccines to those 65 and over or those with conditions that make them more susceptible to severe illness. Meanwhile, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is reeling after the White House fired its director. What questions do you have about the new vaccine policy and the state of the CDC? The Post’s health team is answering your questions during a live chat now. Send in your questions here.

item.title: In Trump’s latest test of Congress’s spending authority, White House cancels nearly $5 billion in previously approved USAID funding
item.description: The administration says it can act with or without approval from lawmakers, under a little-tested theory called a “pocket rescission.”

item.title: How a hacker uncovered the data behind Tesla’s $243 million wrongful death verdict
item.description: The carmaker long said it didn’t have an electric vehicle’s stored digital account of its fatal 2019 crash involving Autopilot. The way that data finally was discovered is believed to have played into a Florida jury’s recent landmark finding that Tesla was partially liable.

item.title: 10 questions, and don't forget the bonus wager! Finish off your week with On the Record.
item.description: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

item.title: Trump revokes Kamala Harris’s Secret Service detail, which had been extended by Biden
item.description: The president’s decision comes as his 2024 Democratic opponent prepares to travel nationwide for a book tour. Federal law gives vice presidents six months of Secret Service protection after they leave office, though President Joe Biden had lengthened her detail into 2026 before he left the White House.

item.title: CDC revolt. Minneapolis victims. Newsom vs. Trump. Tesla. Ultra-processed foods. Weekend forecast. Holiday ranking. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: The U.S. has an ‘impostor nurse’ problem, and it’s grown since the pandemic
item.description: Authorities in numerous states have reported people falsely claiming to be licensed nurses or working in positions that require a nursing license without valid credentials. Staffing shortages, underfunding and a lack of oversight have exacerbated the problem, one expert said.

item.title: White House picks top RFK Jr. deputy to be acting CDC director
item.description: The selection of Jim O'Neill reflects Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s influence as he seeks to remake federal vaccine policy. It comes a day after the White House fired Susan Monarez, the Senate-confirmed director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which prompted a series of resignations of other top CDC officials.

item.title: Cold-case killer gets 22 years in prison for 2001 murder of his ex-girlfriend’s mother in Chevy Chase, Maryland
item.description: Eugene Gligor admitted he murdered Leslie Preer but claimed he doesn’t remember how it happened. And another element remains unknown to authorities: his motive.

item.title: Turmoil at CDC as three agency leaders condemn RFK Jr., resign over director’s ouster; GOP senator urges vaccine meeting delay
item.description: As the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reeled from the ousting of its director, three senior leaders who resigned in protest told The Washington Post they were asked to participate in an unscientific vaccine recommendation process that they believe could harm the health of Americans.

item.title: Federal judge blocks Kari Lake from firing the director of Voice of America
item.description: Judge Royce Lamberth ruled that only a majority vote from the Senate-confirmed board of the broadcaster can fire its director, Michael Abramowitz, dealing a blow to the Trump administration’s effort to dismantle the service.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Conversational calisthenics with mother-in-law who is never direct
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Conversational calisthenics with mother-in-law who is never direct

item.title: Fed governor Lisa Cook sues Trump to block effort to remove her, in a case that could decide central bank independence
item.description: The Trump administration has accused Cook of making false statements on mortgage applications. Cook has yet to respond substantively to the allegations, which have yet to be proved.
